text: if you try to seek asylum in Japan there
is a good chance this is where you'll
end up locked up in the East Japan
migrant detention center
this place looks and feels very much
like a prison right now 300 people are
being held behind bars here most have
committed no crime but we're not allowed
to see them let alone interview them so
this is one of the rooms where the
detainees are killed although this
Allsteel it's very much like a cell and
in here there could be as many as five
people living and they are locked up
inside here for up to 15 hours a day now
there is a toilet in here there's a wash
basin and there is a window but the
windows are blanked off so you can't see
out of them this man knows exactly what
it's like to be locked up in one of
those cells today Aaron yielded him is
happily married with a new baby but
after fleeing to Japan from Turkish
Kurdistan he spent a year and a half
locked up and under daily pressure to
leave home Hashanah hand and a itsuka
every day they told me I was going to
report it they said don't build up any
hopes it's better you go home for
eternity but if you don't we will deport
you to me it was no different from
Guantanamo Bay what I should not had a
human god when if these are detained in
Japan it's the same as prison they may
not physically beat you but they burry
you mentally every day 15 years later
aaron has still not been granted asylum
he can only stay in Japan because his
wife is Japanese
Japan rejects more than 99% of refugee
applications in the last year it has
accepted just three refugees from Syria
in a house in our north of Tokyo this
young man has recently arrived from Iraq
he's applied for asylum that knows he
has little chance while he waits he's
barred from working or even getting a
mobile phone yeah and a health advice
let's our guys gonna be it they give you
no options he says they don't let you
live I just sit here all day it's like
being in prison so in the end you'll
want to leave
Japan's Asylum system appears designed
to grind people down to get them to
leave the detention center cells are
decorated with messages this one in
Chinese in Japan foreign refugees have
no human rights it says Rupert Wingfield
Hays BBC News in Ibaraki Japan
